content.title: Blue Toe Syndrome (Atheroembolism)
content.definition: Blue toe syndrome is acute digital ischemia caused by microembolization of atherosclerotic debris (cholesterol crystals) from proximal arterial sources to the small arteries of the toes, occurring in the presence of palpable pedal pulses.

pathophysiology.mechanism: Cholesterol crystal and atheromatous debris embolization
pathophysiology.source: Proximal atherosclerotic plaque (aorta, iliac, femoral, popliteal)

diagnosis.clinical: Blue toes + palpable pulses + risk factors/procedure

imaging.duplex_ultrasound: Identify proximal source (AAA, iliac, popliteal aneurysm)

diagnosis.biopsy: Skin or muscle showing cholesterol clefts (pathognomonic)

treatment.amputation: For non-viable tissue, limited to affected digits

prognosis.mortality: High (16-30% at 1 year) if systemic involvement
prognosis.limb: Variable - may be limited digital loss or major amputation

learning_objectives: Define blue toe syndrome and distinguish from thromboembolism
Identify triggers and sources of cholesterol embolization
Outline treatment approach including source control
clinical_pearls: Blue toes with palpable pulses is classic presentation
Search for proximal source (AAA, popliteal aneurysm)
High mortality if systemic involvement - treat the source
